metadata.title: Random Forest Overview. A conceptual overview of the Random… | by Kurtis Pykes | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Thanks to amazing open source frameworks like Keras, Tensorflow, Py-torch and Scikit-Learn, Machine learning and Deep learning algorithms have become much more democratized and accessible for…

all_paragraphs: Thanks to amazing open source frameworks like Keras, Tensorflow, Py-torch and Scikit-Learn, Machine learning and Deep learning algorithms have become much more democratized and accessible for everyone to take part in the construction of the next generation. As a result, we no longer have to build any of the algorithms from scratch with our own code because that wheel has already been invented. However, although we can now implement algorithms without having much insight into what is going on under the hood, I strongly believe that it is still extremely important to have a thorough knowledge of what our Machine learning or Deep learning algorithm is doing under the hood because it makes debugging the algorithms much easier so we can better interpret the outcome of a model and use that to carry out deliberate experiments to find procedures that we can use optimize the model.

A good framework to adopt when learning technical concepts is known as the “Top-Down Approach”. Leading practitioners/mentors in the field Jeremy Howard and Rachel Thomas, the founders of fast.ai, constantly advocate for this approach so much that I was provoked to read Paul Lockhart’s book titled “The mathematician's lament” (A book they constantly use to back up this approach). The idea of the top-down approach is to reverse the traditional methods used for conventional learning (i.e. going through years of education of theory before doing practical work) on its head and doing practical work first and then coming back to learn the theory.

I have found that this approach helps me to build a mental model about a particular technical method and so when I visit the theory regarding the technique, I tend to be much more curious about why certain components allow something to work in the way it does.

In this blog post I will be sharing doing an overview about the inner-workings of the Random forest. However, I advise that if you have never implemented a Random forest before that you do so and make some alterations to the hyperparameters (parameters set before training) to get a better idea of how they affect the output of the algorithm, before reading this overview article.

Since there are plenty of very extensive resources covering the Random Forest that will help to get started, I have not prepared my own notebook to walk through, though if I get request to do so I would — leave a response or email me at kurtispykes@gmail.com. Instead, I have linked to a resource that I found extremely helpful when I was learning about Random forest.

In lesson1-rf of the Fast.ai Introduction to Machine learning for coders is a MOOC, Jeremy Howard walks through the Random forest using Kaggle Bluebook for bulldozers dataset. I believe that cloning this repository and waking through the notebook is really useful (even without the videos). My suggestion is to change things within the algorithm until you break it (and try to fix it once you break it) just so that you can get an intuitive understanding of how changing a feature affects the outcome of the models predictions.
P.S. use this link to download the dataset used for this notebook.
CART at the foundations of Random Forest

In order to understand the inner-workings of the Random Forest algorithm, we must first gain an intuitive understanding of Decision Trees. Decision trees are a highly interpretable and important predictive model capable of performing both Classification and Regression task¹- Decision trees is a classical name that was first used for the Algorithm, however it is possible that in more modern textbooks and context that Decision trees may be referred to as CART algorithms which is an acronym denoting Classification and Regression Tree, since this algorithm is capable of both regression and classification.

Though Algorithm’s have a tendency to seem quite complex, CARTs are ever present in our day-to-day lives. As a matter of fact, it still surprises people when they understand how CARTs work and see how much it is like the thought process we use to make decisions. For instance, if I am contemplating what activity to do on the weekend, there are a number of features/variables that I would consider before coming to some conclusion about a task. First, I may consider whether it is going to be raining; if it is going to be raining on the weekend, I may decide to stay home and read a book, however if it is not raining I would consider if Chelsea FC are going to be playing a match this weekend. If Chelsea are playing, I would then ask if they are playing at home or away; If Chelsea are playing at home then I would go to the game, but if they are away then I would continue to ask questions until I come to a Decision about what I want to do on the weekend.

This flowchart like structure is how CARTs work. To put it technically, CARTs try to partition the covariate space by the partition that provides the maximal information gain. Since I believe that sometimes explanations are unnecessarily complex I translate that as, CARTs attempt to split the data into subsets (which is referred to as a Node) — the first Node in the tree is called the Root Node and the Nodes in which the binary-splits are made are called internal Nodes, therefore leaving the Nodes in which no splits are made, and they are called Leaf Nodes — that best separate the outcomes.

To do a binary-split at each node, the algorithm must find the feature (and feature threshold if the feature values are not binary) whom’s split best separates the classes, hence the name information gain, as we are gaining the most information about the final outcome. In order to determine the “best” split, a cost function is defined, such as Gini impurity or Entropy (in practice it does not matter which one you decide to optimise for) for classification task and RMSE (Root Mean Squared Error) for regression task, and the aim is to find the split in the feature space that minimizes these criterions resulting in the optimal split at each steps. Additionally, CARTs are known as greedy algorithms because at each step of the tree the algorithm attempts to make the optimal split in order for it to reach the globally optimal solution.

Without regularization, better known as pruning in tree structures, the tree will recursively split at each node until each node until each leaf node is left with a single outcome. Although in our scenario of deciding what activity we should on the weekend this is great, as we will always come to a conclusion on what activity we should do, in applied Machine learning this is a major issue because the algorithm would fail to generalize (which is the whole purpose of applied Machine Learning) to unseen instances since it simply memorizes the training data — this is known as overfitting.

There are various pruning methods to combat CARTs failure to generalize, but these techniques often result in a reduction of accuracy during training and reducing the complexity of the Algorithm. Using multiple Decision trees and taking the average of the trees (Regression) or taking the majority vote (Classification) quickly became known as the solution to this problem, and from this Random Forest was born. The goal was to maintain the complexity of trees whilst keeping a high accuracy on training data and allowing for an algorithm that can generalize well to unseen instances.

1) Define a cost function i.e. Gini index or Entropy (Classification) RMSE or MAE(Regression) 2) Perform binary split on the feature that minimise cost function 2) Repeat step 2 until you reach leaf node in all branches

Take a moment to think of a forest. A forest is made up of a multitude of individual trees. When we identify a group of items as whole rather than individually, we refer to this as an ‘Ensemble’, therefore a forest is an ensemble that is made up of a multitude of individual trees (keep this in mind as we break down the Random forest algorithm).

The Random forest is an ensemble method (it groups multiple Decision tree predictors) which was developed by Leo Breiman in 2001². In [2] Breiman states that ‘The generalization error of a forest of tree classifiers depends on the strength of the individual trees in the forest and the correlation between them’. With that being said, Random forest use an effective method called bootstrap aggregation³, as well as the random subspace method⁴ to grow individual trees to achieve an extremely powerful aggregated predictor, capable of classification and regression, with better generalization error than an individual Decision tree.

Bootstrap aggregating or quite simply, Bagging, is a method that is used to generate multiple versions of a predictor and using the predictors to achieve an aggregated predictor [3]. Randomness is introduced into each predictor by making bootstrap replicates —randomly sampling instances from the training set with replacement — and using this as the new bootstrap data as the training set. Note that instances are being replaced back into the original training set when they are randomly sampled into the bootstrap set, therefore it is likely that some instances would occur more than once in the bootstrap training set that the predictor is trained on. Additionally, each bootstrap sample fed into each predictive model is of the same distribution.

The aggregated predictor, in this instance is our Random forest, outputs an average over the predictions of each Decision tree when we are solving a regression style problem — we are trying to predict a continuous outcome such as the price of a house. On the other hand, when we are doing classification task — we are trying to predict some discrete label such as whether an image is a Cat — our Random forest outputs the relative majority of the predictions of each model.

In [4] Kam Ho Tin proposed Random subspace method as a means of increasing generalization accuracy of Decision tree classifiers without trading away accuracy on training data by reducing the correlation between the predictive models in an ensemble. This method is similar to bagging in a sense that each predictive model within the ensemble is trained on a random sample of features with replacement, instead of training the model on the all the features. This technique allows for the predictors to not focus all of its attention on the features that appear more predictive than others.

The techniques mentioned above are introduced into the Random forest to reduce the correlation of each predictor, trading variance for some bias. Although each individual Decision tree is in essence overfitting — each tree individually scores 100% on the training data — the training data and features used to build each tree is different. The result of the prior adjustments is that the Decision tree models are less correlated and make different errors, in turn resulting in the models complementing each other in correctness.

Another way to improve the generalization error of the Random forest is to improve the strength of each individual tree. By building trees that have a strong prediction accuracy (lowering the error rate of the tree), we decrease the overall error rate of the Random forest.

Reducing m reduces both the correlation and the strength. Increasing it increases both. Somewhere in between is an ”optimal” range of m — usually quite wide. This is the only adjustable parameter to which random forests is somewhat sensitive².

A very useful mechanism in the Random forest is something called the OOB (Out-of-Bag) error. This is a technique that is used to evaluate the error rate in models that use bootstrap aggregation (Bagging) to gain bootstrap samples that are used for training. OOB is the derived by making predictions using only the instances that was not selected in the bootstrap sample to build the tree.

1) For a training set of length N, sample N instances at random with replacement.2) Grow a tree on the bootstrap training set using a specified number of random features 3) Repeat step 1 and 2 for the set number of estimators.4) Average predictions or take majority vote (depending on type of task)

Random forest are an extremely powerful ensemble method. Though they may no longer win Kaggle competitions, in the real world where 0.0001 extra accuracy does not matter much (in most circumstances) the Random forest is a highly effective model to use to begin experimenting.

P.S. Kaggle has been regarded as the “Home of Data Science” and in all fairness, it is not hard to see why. There is an excellent feature called notebooks in which people share their code. This a good way to begin if you just want to run some algorithm. A good idea is to change some features and try to beat their score, i’ve found that really helps with learning.
Other post that I would recommend to build on your knowledge of Random forest are:
